text:
PROFESSOR: The first
project for the semester

was designing a outside place
in a quarry north of Boston,
in Rockport.

We have gone to the
quarry, and they

were asked-- the
students were asked

to find a place in the
quarry that they liked,

photograph it, sketch it,
understand it, bring it back

to the studio, and then design
a classroom for themselves

and me that was
sheltered, not enclosed.

But the idea was making a
place in the quarry that

was neither natural or was
it to appear to be built.

It was to fit into the
context of the quarry.

They were welcome to use any
materials that they thought
would relate to the quarry.

When they came back
from the quarry,

I then asked them to
do their first design

and their first
ideas of the quarry.

So what you're about to
see is the very first pin

up of the semester, of
this very first project.
AUDIENCE: So when I saw that--

because the best thing about
it was how nature is really--
it's got a logic to it.

And every gap and
everything that's there
is filled in in some ways.
There's something lost.
There's nothing wasted.

Everything belongs in
that net of things.
And so when I--

I decided that my site
would be right here,
where all the seagulls were.

I figured that the seagulls
would know better than me
what the best place was.

Nature has that logic,
so the animals did too.

And also, I realized that
it was daylight outside.

But if you notice,
it's got a lot of--
it basically is a cliff cutout.

And what I'm trying to
do is fill that space,

as nature does, to have
that space filled in.

And this is what the
site looks like now.
There are the seagulls.

And then this is what I'm
hoping to do, is to fill that,

to just make it look
like how it used to be--

how I imagined it to have been
before, when nature was already
present in the [INAUDIBLE].

And I like the idea
of just [INAUDIBLE]..

Here, it shows just how even
the grass and the ground

and the soil evens
out on the rocks,
even though they're jagged.
So evening things out--

here's the site-- hoping
that I'll just even that out
in a way.

Also, when I was
sitting there, I
was listening to the seagulls.

And they were a
little bit annoying

at times, but just the sound
in the water splashing,

the sound of them
just flying around,

the wind rustling
of all the plants

and things-- that was also
part of the experience.

And I'm hoping to coexist
with the seagulls.
This is the site.
[INAUDIBLE]
Seagulls live in here.

I saw this small space here as
a private area also, and here

as a private area, and then this
bigger space as a common place.

I'm looking at the studio
as more of a dynamic place

rather than all of
us having our desks.

This is my idea, is adding
a stone wall to the side
so that it blends.

And I just-- I'm
very literal about--

I just imagine these
trees just growing out

of those gaps in the rocks
and them making a canopy
and intertwining at the top.

And sort of like how
will we enter the space?

It became this, like,
tunnel of canopy of plants.

That's sort of what I want
to do that with of plants.

And people sitting
around with the drawing

boards on their laps,
moving around, going down
here to look out.
That's the idea.
Here's my model.

I was thinking of
stairways on the side
and then going all the way down.

And the steps from one
space to the other.

PROFESSOR: What did
you just take away?
AUDIENCE: These were the steps.
PROFESSOR: Oh, OK.
AUDIENCE: Yeah.

Well, I could take
out all the pieces
and have you see the original.

But basically, I
added the stone walls.
And I'm thinking of using--

I don't feel like I want
to disturb the environment.

I feel like I want to
use what's already there.

The space is telling
me, this is useful.
Use me as such.
This was a sitting area.
That is a drawing board.
This is a drawing board.

I don't want-- I feel like I
can just work with what I have,

fill that space in, and
not disturb anyone--

none of the animals
nor the plant life.

PROFESSOR: Can you just talk
a little bit about that?
Because it's quite different.

It looks quite different
in your sketch.
AUDIENCE: OK.

Well, this is the abstract
version of the sketch.

Since the spot that I picked
is going to be very sunny,

I wanted to take
advantage of that.

So I want something
that would be clear,

but I also created some
shadow, some movement, too.

And in some ways, I'm
trying to use this

as a tunnel on this
side and maybe up here--

so the curvature of the roof--
so that it traps light in

and it brings it into
the space, and it

might bounce off from the top
and go down to the studio.

But I just imagine it just
growing out of the ground.
I'm just covering it up again.

PROFESSOR: It's a
very, very good start.

And then that gives me
a license to negligence,

now that I've done
that [INAUDIBLE]..

I'm really impressed,
also, how quickly

we have understood the
quarries and the subtleties

of the observations
that you've made.

I think the idea of coexisting
with the seagulls is wonderful.

I don't know how to do that
and if you can do that.
But I have to tell you a story.

I have a little summer
house where I was,

in which two young deer
have decided is their house.
AUDIENCE: Oh, boy.
PROFESSOR: And they--

I was there, and
they were there.

And they were wondering why
I was there because they're
there more than I'm there.

And we became friends over a
couple of days, the two fawns.
They're about that size-- dogs.

And you said the word,
and I said it, coexist.
I think we could live together.

So the sensitivity
towards the seagulls,

which might have more
problems than the deer--

I don't know-- in certain
ways, is wonderful.

And how you do
that, I don't know.

One is very interesting
to me, again,

from the observation
of the seagull place.
I think you're right.

I think the seagulls
know something,
that they know more than you do.
They've been around a while.

I don't know, again,
how happy they're

going to be about you
moving [INAUDIBLE]..

They'll let you know
if they do or not.

But I think it's a very
good observation, that this
is a natural kind of place.
[INAUDIBLE]

The translation of
that into what you say,

which is the case with all of us
in the beginning as architects
and what we do, is different.
And that's our job.

That's what this is all about,
to try to get the head down

to the body, out to the
hands, and into this,
what it is we need.

And we're not going
to get frightened.

And I've been at it for a few
years longer than you have.

When you see, when I
show you my own work,

that I don't care
about it either.
None of us do.

I would like to challenge and
question whether, in this case,

the notion of this
cover need to be

as organic as what
you're suggesting here
because when I see--

when I saw this, there is
something already very elegant

about the abstraction of
this cover and support.
Do people see that?
It's quite beautiful.

I was sitting over
there, looking at it.

And the curved forms
in the way that you

have started to address the
solvent is quite wonderful--

more wonderful in my mind
than what's in your mind,
which is this.
And this is a takeoff.
I mean, this is the beginning.

But where would you
correctly translate

the architectural form from
this great [INAUDIBLE]??
It's not clear to me.
There could be another form.

As an example, these could
be even more sails that
might move around and flutter--
canvas, different materials.

But it's very, very
powerful, the form

of this, related to the
quality of underneath.

I also think, in this
one, it's very exciting

that she has made
some changes on it--
added to it.
But we've reinforced the place.

So you are, what I would
say, very contextual.

You've taken what's
there, followed

the clue of the seagulls,
and tried to improve it.

Good start, but you're
only halfway there

in terms of the
architectural form.

But you're a good halfway
there in the sense

that you're relating
this to the nature,

to the quarry, and
this to the sky.
I think this is horrible.
AUDIENCE: Yeah, I agree.
PROFESSOR: You got a better one.

This looks like a fire
escape coming down

the second means of
egress, which is not
what our [INAUDIBLE].

This is a little bit
better but still could
be a little bit more subtle.
I don't know where I'm talking.
You had me the other day here.
I don't want to be there.
Thank you.
I'd rather be someplace else.

So be careful about suggesting
where the classroom is

in terms of the direction of
it because professors may not

want to be where
you want them to be.
But good start.
